hints.Pitch: The highness or lowness of a musical sound, determined by the frequency of its vibrations.
hints.Rhythm: The arrangement of sounds and silences in time, creating a pattern of beats and accents.
hints.Melody: A series of pitches played in a sequence, forming a recognizable musical idea.
hints.Harmony: The simultaneous combination of pitches, creating chords and chord progressions.
hints.Dynamics: The volume or loudness of a musical sound, indicated by symbols such as p (piano) for soft and f (forte) for loud.
hints.Tempo: The speed or pace of a piece of music, measured in beats per minute (BPM).
hints.Articulation: The way notes are played, such as smoothly (legato) or detached (staccato).
hints.Form: The overall structure of a piece of music, including sections and phrases.
hints.Timbre: The unique quality or tone color of a musical sound, which distinguishes it from other instruments or voices.
hints.Key signature: A set of sharps or flats at the beginning of a staff, indicating the key of the piece.
hints.Time signature: A symbol that shows how many beats are in each measure and what type of note gets one beat.
hints.Note values: The duration of a note, such as a whole note, half note, quarter note, etc.
hints.Rest values: The duration of silence in music, corresponding to the note values.
hints.Musical symbols: Signs and symbols used in sheet music to represent various elements of music.
hints.Intervals: The distance between two pitches, measured in steps or half steps.
hints.Scales: A series of pitches in ascending or descending order, such as major, minor, or pentatonic scales.
hints.Chords: A group of three or more pitches played simultaneously or in close succession.
hints.Triads: A type of chord consisting of three pitches, such as major, minor, diminished, or augmented triads.
hints.Phrases: Short musical ideas or sections, usually 4 to 8 measures long, that make up a melody or larger musical structure.
hints.Motifs: A short musical idea, usually just a few notes, that is repeated or developed throughout a piece of music.
